message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of hyphae suggests a fungal infection, and the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this is topical selenium sulfide, which is commonly used to treat fungal skin infections. Oral fluconazole and ketoconazole are systemic antifungal agents and are not typically used to treat skin infections. Topical corticosteroids are used to reduce inflammation and itching, but would not be effective against a fungal infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of long hyphae among clusters of yeast cells in the skin scraping suggests a fungal infection, specifically tinea versicolor. Topical selenium sulfide is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for tinea versicolor. Oral fluconazole and oral ketoconazole may be used for other fungal infections, while a topical corticosteroid may exacerbate the fungal infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Long hyphae among clusters of yeast cells suggest pityriasis versicolor, which is a skin infection caused by a type of yeast. Topical selenium sulfide is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for treating pityriasis versicolor. Oral ketoconazole or fluconazole can be used, but they are not the first line of treatment. Topical corticosteroids are not effective for treating fungal infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of both hyphae and yeast cells suggest tinea versicolor, which is caused by Malassezia furfur. Topical antifungal medication like selenium sulfide is indicated for this condition. Oral fluconazole and ketoconazole may be used in severe cases, but topical treatment is usually sufficient. Topical corticosteroids are not recommended as they can worsen fungal infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of long hyphae among clusters of yeast cells is characteristic of tinea versicolor caused by Malassezia furfur, and topical selenium sulfide is the most appropriate treatment for this condition. Oral fluconazole or ketoconazole may be used for systemic fungal infections, but they are not the first-line treatment for tinea versicolor. Topical corticosteroids are not effective against fungal infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of both hyphae and yeast cells suggests a diagnosis of tinea versicolor, which is commonly caused by a type of yeast called Malassezia. Topical selenium sulfide is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for treating tinea versicolor. Oral fluconazole and ketoconazole can be used for systemic infections caused by Malassezia but are not the first-line treatment for tinea versicolor. Topical corticosteroids should not be used for fungal infections as they can worsen the infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of both hyphae and yeast cells in the microscopical findings suggests a diagnosis of tinea versicolor, which is caused by Malassezia species. Topical selenium sulfide is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy. The other options are used for different types of fungal infections.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of long hyphae among clusters of yeast cells suggests a diagnosis of pityriasis versicolor caused by Malassezia furfur. Topical selenium sulfide is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this condition. Oral fluconazole or ketoconazole can also be used, but topical therapy is preferred as it has fewer side effects. Topical corticosteroids are not effective for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Long hyphae among clusters of yeast cells suggest Tinea versicolor, which is caused by Malassezia furfur. Topical selenium sulfide is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for Tinea versicolor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of long hyphae among clusters of yeast cells indicates a fungal infection, specifically tinea versicolor. Topical selenium sulfide is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this condition. Oral fluconazole and oral ketoconazole may also be effective, but topical treatment is preferred for limited disease. Topical corticosteroids should not be used as monotherapy for fungal infections as they can exacerbate the infection.
